articles.headline: Behind Staid Steel, a Percolating Boardroom Drama
articles.snippet: The story of GrafTech illustrates the complex dynamics when relations between directors and management turn sour. It also highlights the sensitivity inside the boardroom in an era of activist investors and insider trading.
articles.abstract: The story of GrafTech illustrates the complex dynamics when relations between directors and management turn sour. It also highlights the sensitivity inside the boardroom in an era of activist investors and insider trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:57 p.m. | When Craig S. Shular, the chief executive of a small steel company called GrafTech International, retired on Tuesday, it looked like just another management changeover at a midmarket industrial company.

articles.headline: Key Witness Says Leader of SAC Was F.B.I. Target
articles.snippet: The prosecution’s top witness said F.B.I. agents told him the government’s true target was Steven A. Cohen, SAC’s billionaire founder.
articles.abstract: The prosecution’s top witness said F.B.I. agents told him the government’s true target was Steven A. Cohen, SAC’s billionaire founder.
articles.lead_paragraph: The man whose shadow has been hanging over the insider trading trial of Mathew Martoma, the former SAC Capital Advisors trader, took center stage on Thursday when the prosecution’s top witness said F.B.I. agents told him the government’s true target was Steven A. Cohen, SAC’s billionaire founder.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Neiman Marcus Data Breach Worse Than First Said
articles.snippet: The theft of consumer data from the luxury retailer appears to have involved 1.1 million credit and debit cards.
articles.abstract: The theft of consumer data from the luxury retailer appears to have involved 1.1 million credit and debit cards.
articles.lead_paragraph: The theft of consumer data from Neiman Marcus appears far deeper than had been disclosed originally, with the luxury retailer now saying that hackers invaded its systems for several months in a breach that involved 1.1 million credit and debit cards.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris, Nicole Perlroth and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: Don’t Expect Job Data Alone to Persuade Fed on Rates
articles.snippet: As the Fed grew more optimistic about the unemployment rate, it grew less optimistic about overall economic growth.
articles.abstract: As the Fed grew more optimistic about the unemployment rate, it grew less optimistic about overall economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just over a year ago, the Federal Reserve changed its guidance on how long it planned to keep interest rates very low.

articles.headline: Speeding Up G.M.’s Comeback
articles.snippet: In her first extended public comments since taking over General Motors, Mary Barra vowed to quicken its comeback with improved products, better brands and consistently profitable operations around the world.
articles.abstract: In her first extended public comments since taking over General Motors, Mary Barra vowed to quicken its comeback with improved products, better brands and consistently profitable operations around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — No matter how much attention she draws as the auto industry’s first female chief executive, Mary T. Barra is determined to keep the focus on cars and trucks at General Motors.

articles.headline: Hospital Chain Said to Scheme to Inflate Bills
articles.snippet: Whistle-blower suits claim Health Management Associates tried to inflate its Medicare and Medicaid payments by admitting more patients.
articles.abstract: Whistle-blower suits claim Health Management Associates tried to inflate its Medicare and Medicaid payments by admitting more patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every day the scorecards went up, where they could be seen by all of the hospital’s emergency room doctors.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Reed Abelson

articles.headline: In Rural Jails, E-Cigarettes Are a Calming Vapor
articles.snippet: Cash-strapped county jails are finding that the sale of e-cigarettes to inmates can provide a lucrative source of income.
articles.abstract: Cash-strapped county jails are finding that the sale of e-cigarettes to inmates can provide a lucrative source of income.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAFAYETTE, Tenn. — As city governments and schools across the country move to ban or restrict the use of electronic cigarettes, one place increasingly welcomes the devices: the rural county jail.

articles.headline: Fined Billions, JPMorgan Chase Will Give Dimon a Raise
articles.snippet: In a series of contentious meetings, JPMorgan Chase’s board voted to give Jamie Dimon a new pay package after his pay was cut in half last year, to $11.5 million.
articles.abstract: In a series of contentious meetings, JPMorgan Chase’s board voted to give Jamie Dimon a new pay package after his pay was cut in half last year, to $11.5 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after an embarrassing trading blowup led to millions of dollars being docked from Jamie Dimon’s paycheck, the chairman and chief executive of JPMorgan Chase is getting a raise.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Prolonged Fight Feared in Egypt After Bombings
articles.snippet: Four deadly bombings left a grim realization that a cycle of terrorism and repression is hardening the wills of the military-backed government and a growing Islamist insurgency to fight to the death.
articles.abstract: Four deadly bombings left a grim realization that a cycle of terrorism and repression is hardening the wills of the military-backed government and a growing Islamist insurgency to fight to the death.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Three years after the start of its revolt for democracy, the capital was shaken Friday by four deadly bombings, in the clearest sign yet that Egypt is entering a prolonged and violent struggle between the military-backed government and a growing Islamist insurgency.

articles.headline: Chip Profits Help Soften Other Losses at Samsung
articles.snippet: A slide in smartphone sales was partly offset by the company’s hold on vital handset components, which are often sold to Apple and other competitors.
articles.abstract: A slide in smartphone sales was partly offset by the company’s hold on vital handset components, which are often sold to Apple and other competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the marketplace, Samsung Electronics and Apple battle for customers. In the courts, they fight over patents. Yet every time Apple sells an iPhone, Samsung quietly cheers, too.
